awd_abstract_narration:
Technological developments are bringing more sophisticated automation and greater levels of machine autonomy to the global airspace (National Research Council, 2014). Despite this, the human operator remains indispensable to the aviation system, filling roles that include pilot, air traffic controller, aircraft dispatcher, and aircraft and air navigation system maintenance worker. These roles evolve with technology but are not displaced by it. Aviation systems must therefore be built to accommodate the operators’ abilities and limitations. Effective human-machine integration translates fundamental knowledge of human performance into sound design choices.  

The International Symposium on Aviation Psychology (ISAP) is a biennial meeting that convenes scientists, operators, and research sponsors to bridge the gap between basic perceptual/cognitive science and applications in aviation system design. At the same time, ISAP recognizes the need to foster exchange of basic knowledge and insights across domains of application. It welcomes all basic and applied research into the role of humans in human-machine systems that supports generalizations to or from aerospace psychology. The 22nd ISAP, to be hosted by the Rochester Institute of Technology in Rochester, NY, will present cutting-edge research on human cognition and performance within sociotechnical systems, foster collaboration between researchers, engineers, and aviation operational personnel, both from the civilian and the military sectors, and envision design solutions that match aviation technology to human capabilities. The NSF support will enable the construction of an affordable, high-quality program that will draw diverse and broadly interdisciplinary groups of prominent researchers, students, and aviation practitioners representing the academic, industry, and government sectors from around the world with the common goal of ensuring a safe and efficient air transportation system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The International Symposium on Aviation Psychology (ISAP) was first convened by Prof. Richard Jensen at the Ohio State University in 1981. ISAP is a venue for research on human performance within aviation systems, and for design solutions tailored to human capabilities and constraints. It meets for the purposes of:

(a) Presenting the latest research on human performance problems and opportunities within aviation systems;

(b) Envisioning design solutions that best utilize human capabilities for creating safe and efficient aviation systems; and

(c) Bringing together scientists, research sponsors, and operators in an effort to bridge the gap between research and application.

Although the symposium is aerospace oriented, any basic or applied research in any domain that may be generalized from or to the aviation domain are relevant.

The 22nd ISAP was convened at Rochester Institute of Technology in Rochester, NY, USA, from May 31 to June 3, 2023. The symposium had 148 attendees from 14 countries, including representatives from the US Government, from FAA, NASA, and USAF, as well as from several airlines. A total of 66 technical papers were presented in 3 parallel sessions during the symposium in addition to 4 panel discussions, including the Practitioners’ and Researchers’ Panels, and 3 keynote addresses:

(1) Dr. Vernol Battiste, San Jose State University Research Foundation at NASA Ames Research Center: Towards A Distributed Air Traffic Management System In the National Airspace System – From Centralized to Decentralized Air Traffic Management

(2) Dr. Cleotilde (Coty) Gonzales, Social and Decision Sciences Department and Dynamic Decision Making Laboratory at Carnegie Mellon University: Building Human-Like Artificial Agents: A General Cognitive Algorithm to Emulate Human Dynamic Decision Making

(3) Dr. Mary (Missy) Cummings, George Mason University Mechanical Engineering, Electrical and Computer Engineering and Computer Science: Promises and Perils of AI in Safety-Critical Systems

Over 20% of the participants were students. Six students participated in the Stanley Roscoe Best Student Paper Competition; the winner was Naomi Paul from the University of Waterloo. This was the first scientific conference the majority of the students had participated in, due to our efforts to keep the cost of participation low (discounted student registration fee, available student housing on RIT campus), helping students present their research, learn from others, and to network.

The papers presented at the 22nd ISAP are archived at the Wright State University Libraries Collections (https://corescholar.libraries.wright.edu/isap_2023), adding to a body of literature on current state of research on aviation psychology in response to contemporary challenges (unmanned areal vehicles, urban air mobility, artificial intelligence-driven automation in aviation systems, &c.).

The 22nd ISAP carried on the 44-year history of ISAP and there was palpable enthusiasm among the participants to keep the tradition alive, as ISAP is indeed unique among scientific meetings by the diverse groups it brings together. The symposium program heavily weighted towards social events (daily lunches and social events each evening of the symposium) offering much time and many opportunities for informal meetings between the participants to exchange research ideas and results and to form future collaborative partnerships.

The 23rd ISAP will be held on May 27-30, 2025, at Oregon State University in Corvallis, OR.
